title: Birdwatching in Armenia

about_birdwatching.about:
Birdwatching is a hobby dedicated to observing birds in their natural environment. Many people take binoculars and cameras and devote their time to this pastime. They can put data about their walks and observations in specialized databases, thereby contributing to science and conservation efforts.

The research uses data from ebird.org from January 2018 to December 2024.
about_birdwatching.p2: Each entry in the database represents one species observed by one birdwatcher during a single walk.
about_birdwatching.p3: The graph shows the dynamic development of birdwatching in Armenia. The dip in 2020, in addition to the reduction in trips by the local population, may be caused by the closure of borders worldwide and the absence of international birdwatchers traveling in the country. This indirectly suggests that a significant portion of birdwatchers consists of foreign groups.
about_birdwatching.p4: In 2020, there was a noticeable decline in the number of observed species. This may indicate that birdwatchers limited the geographic scope of their trips during the pandemic. For instance, they observed more birds in cities near their place of residence rather than going on long trips.
about_birdwatching.p5: The largest number of observations falls in May. This is the peak time for bird arrivals. Most bird species become noticeable and actively sing.

about_locations:
Thanks to its diverse landscapes—from mountains and forests to steppes and lakes—the country is home to many bird species.

The Armash Fishponds are a key location for birdwatchers. There are over 12,000 birdwatcher entries on ebird.org from this site. In addition to its picturesque views (including Mount Ararat), you can find over 200 bird species here, ranging from common gulls to vultures and pink flamingos.

The Norashen Reserve is called the Island of Gulls. Here, you can see the Armenian, Caspian, and Mediterranean gulls, among others. The reserve is located on the shores of Lake Sevan.

Mount Aragats is the highest mountain range in Armenia. You can encounter various species of larks, buntings, and redstarts, as well as birds of prey like the griffon vulture and the eagle.

One of the most beautiful tourist spots, the Noravank Monastery, is also a popular birdwatching site. This ancient complex, built between the 13th and 15th centuries, is surrounded by red cliffs. Here, you can find the golden eagle, several species of vultures, storks, falcons, and other birds. The Noravank area is also listed as an important bird conservation area.

about_species:
Located at the crossroads of East and West, Armenia boasts a rich diversity of fauna, including over 300 bird species. You can find one-third of the bird species that inhabit Europe here.

Among the birds of prey in Armenia, you can find the steppe eagle and the Caucasian goshawk, among others. They predominantly inhabit mountainous regions.

The rare Caucasian grouse lives in high-altitude forests and alpine meadows. The Bearded vulture, typical of rocky areas, has a large wingspan and plays an important role in the ecosystem as a scavenger.

You can spot flamingos at Lake Sevan. They stop here during their migration.

about_dataset:
Birdwatchers can enter data about their observations into the ebird.org ebird.org project database in the form of checklists . Users note information about the location, time, number of birds seen, and their species.

he project was created and is maintained by the Cornell Lab of Ornithology at Cornell University. It was launched in 2002 and has since become one of the largest and most popular bird observation databases.

The project's data is open. However, for security reasons, records of species requiring special protection are not included in the open datasets.
